title.value: A Probabilistic Framework for Mutation Testing in Deep Neural Networks
title.justification: The title is taken from the start of the provided paper.
title.quote: A Probabilistic Framework for Mutation Testing in Deep Neural Networks

extractions.description: This paper proposes a Probabilistic Mutation Testing (PMT) framework for deep neural networks (DNNs), addressing the flakiness problem in current mutation testing (MT) methods caused by the stochastic nature of DNN training. The PMT framework aims to provide a more consistent decision-making process for identifying killed mutants. The study evaluates PMT using three models and multiple mutation operators, comparing its efficacy with traditional MT methods, and analyzing the trade-offs between approximation error and computational cost.

type.justification: The study involves the implementation and evaluation of a new framework (PMT) compared to existing methods, with empirical analysis of the results.
type.quote: We evaluate our PMT framework using three models/datasets and eight mutation operators and show how our proposed approach can alleviate the flakiness issue.

name.justification: The research revolves around software testing, specifically mutation testing, applied to deep neural networks.
name.quote: Mutation Testing (MT) is an important tool in traditional Software Engineering (SE) white-box testing.

name.justification: The paper focuses on the application of mutation testing techniques to deep neural networks.
name.quote: It is only recently that it started gaining the attention of the Deep Learning (DL) community, with researchers adapting it to improve the testability of DL models.

name.justification: The research also intersects with machine learning in general, as it involves training and evaluating neural network models.
name.quote: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are gaining traction with countless applications, Deep Neural Networks (DNN) being one of the most prominent components.

name.justification: The paper describes the use of a convolutional neural network for the MNIST dataset in its experiments.
name.quote: We chose the model using MNIST [15], with the same DeepCrime architecture and hyper-parameters, as well as the delete training data mutation operator.

is_compared.justification: The CNN model's performance is compared using the proposed PMT framework and traditional MT methods.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate our PMT framework using three models/datasets and eight mutation operators and show how our proposed approach can alleviate the flakiness issue.
